dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small, mod apartment (high-rise, city lights, etc.). We're at a party: with-it people in cocktail clothes, most of them slender, the women playing up bodies. Liquor, dishes of nuts, pretzels, candy on every table. UNDER THE TITLES and STAR CAST CREDITS: The hostess, PATTY, very thin and sexy, refills drinks, serves rich hors d'oeuvres to the guests who are in- volved in a game of charades. Most guests take some- thing, a few refuse. PHIL, very macho, acts out the book title: "LOOKING OUT FOR #1." AD LIBS of... "seeking," "searching," "looking"... "Looking, looking" ... etc, During that we BECOME AWARE of certain of the guests: MARGE, rather rolly-polly, tires of the game, takes hors d'oeuvres tray to help Patty.

dialogues.speaker: MARGE
dialogues.text: Let me help, Patty.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: Oh, thanks, Marge. Marge eats a few as she passes them around. JACK, mid-thirties, slim, nice-looking, just beginning to bald, is more interested in the very young redhead beside him than in the game -- and she in him. On Jack's other side, VICKY, Jack's wife, quite overweight, wearing a too-tight pantsuit, but very atractive and vivacious, steals a disapproving look at Jack, and then turns back to the game. Phil is now pointing to him- self and gesturing "1." TITLES END.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: "Looking Out For Number 1!’ AD LIB applause and agreement. Patty hands an hors d'oeuvre tray to Phil, as she kisses him.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: Brilliant, Phil, darling. Now you can be host again. During that, Vicky polishes off a handful of nuts, and gets up to be next. She takes the folded paper that's handed to her, reads it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Oh, no! Oh, come on! This sounds like something my husband would dream up. (to Jack) Jack, did you? Jack glances at her, shakes his head, no, and goes back to the redhead. Vicky watches until:

dialogues.speaker: MARGE
dialogues.text: Come on, Vicky, start. AD LIB urging, and Vicky gestures that she's starting. She makes the proper gestures for AD LIBBED reactions: "Book title’... "Five words"... "Non-fiction"... "com- plete title"... Vicky begins to run in place. AD LIBS: "Hurry"... "Chase"... "race"... Vicky gestures "keep trying"... as she runs toward Jack, runs in place in front of him, until --

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (turning toward her) Run? She gestures "yes," and to keep trying... and runs harder -- as Jack turns back to the redhead. Vicky notes that, disapproving, and then is drawn back to the game. AD LIBS: “Run, Spot, Run?"... "Maybe it's not run," etc., as Patty and Marge pass food trays and Phil refills wine glasses. He pours for a PAUNCHY MAN.

dialogues.speaker: PAUNCHY MAN
dialogues.text: I hope it's dry wine. Dry has less calories.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Drink up. You can fast tomorrow. Patty, turning to the game:

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: "Run For Your Life’? Vicky gestures no, try again... and runs harder, really lifting her legs, and racing hard in place. She ges- tures a full circle with her arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're BEHIND her as: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARGE
dialogues.text: I've got it, I've got it! ‘The Complete Book of Running'! Applause. Vicky takes a deep, thankful bow and -- her pants split -- in full view of those behind her. There's an awkward silence as those who don't see it react to those who do. Vicky stands, frozen for a moment. Jack is embarrassed, turns away from the red-~ head. And then. Vicky grins widely (a facade), turns so everyone can see the ripped pants, and throws her hands up in a champion's gesture.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: The winner and new champion, Vicky Matthews! The room erupts into applause and laughter. Jack re- laxes, and turns his attention back to the redhead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A glamorous bedroom, with one corner used as a sewing room -- materials and supplies neatly stashed in cubbyholes over a sewing machine, with a slender form wearing a half-finished disco dress standing next to it. Vicky is easing out of the torn pants, as Patty goes through her clothes in the closet. She takes out various items, a dress, a pair of pants, a robe, all sexy, all too small for Vicky, as --

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Why did you invite the redhead?

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: I didn't. Phil did.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: So why doesn't she hit on Phil?

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: She likes husbands better. than boyfriends. How about this? Showing Vicky a filmy robe.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Oh, sure! Patty, none of that is going to fit me. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Vicky wraps the torn pants around herself, and goes to the sewing machine.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: (continuing) Why don't you make yourself a caftan?

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: I don't like them. They camouflage everything.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: (patting her hip) Yeah... everything. She goes through the pile of neatly folded materials.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: Phil likes me in tight, revealing clothes.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Everything I have is tight, and revealing. Of course, none of it started out that way. {picks up a piece of material with a loud, splashy print) Hey, how about.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: Vicky! That's for my new couch cover.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Perfect for me.

dialogues.speaker: THE LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: MUSIC is PLAYING now, and people standing around talk- ing, eating, as Vicky appears in a "sari" made of the bright, splashy print.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Ta-da! Vicky holds a model's pose -- gets applause and laugh- ter from those around her... and a glare from Jack. Then he turns back to the redhead. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Vicky sees that, the smile drops and she moves to the hors d'oeuvres table. Marge is there, relishing the pastries.

dialogues.speaker: MARGE
dialogues.text: The cream puffs are great. Vicky nods and takes one -- and a drink in her other hand -- all with an "I'll show you" determination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack drives a large Oldsmobile sedan, and Vicky, still in the sari, sits beside him. Both are angry. The car RADIO counterpoints with romantic MUSIC.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: IL think I look very... exotic.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You look like you couldn't find anything big enough in Patty's closet.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: (comically) Poor girl is just skin and bones. They ride a moment, silently. The MUSIC ENDS, and a commercial comes on: A.JINGLE advertising a well- known candy. Vicky flicks OFF the RADIO.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: (continuing; digging) And you don't like your women bony. You like them popping out of their clothes. She makes a simpery, sexy gesture.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: All right, Vicky --

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: (imitating him) All I did was talk to the girl.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (exactly the same way) All I did was talk -- (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cc)

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (a take, realizes) She's a nice girl.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: If you happen to like sexy looking broads.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I married a sexy looking broad. He looks at her accusingly. Vicky flinches under it, looks for a retort, then --

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Well... well... I married a guy with hair on his head. Jack's hand goes automatically to his head to cover a thin spot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A suburban, upper-middle class house. A vintage Ford coupe is parked to one side of the driveway, almost blocking the other side. The Oldsmobile pulls in off the street, has to angle around the Ford, going onto the grass, before it can get to the garage.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Your mother didn't move her car. Didn't you tell her?

dialogues.speaker: VICKY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I told her. The garage door opens automatically, revealing a late model Chevy wagon, parked behind the Ford. The Olds pulls into the garage next to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicky and Jack have just come in. Vicky is still hold- ing the ripped pants. HELEN, Vicky's mother, is maternal and very slender. She reaches for her coat, purse and knitting and looks Vicky over at the same time.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: You didn't go to a costume party. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cc) 7

dialogues.speaker: HELEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How come you came home from one? Vicky holds the pants up for Helen to see. And then she mouths with Helen --

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: (continuing) I told you the pants were too tight.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: I know you did, Mom. Thanks for sitting. (heading for the bedroom) Kids give you any trouble?

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: They never give me trouble. Helen looks at Jack.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: (continuing; gesturing a fat body Do something with her.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I'm trying, Helen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Im addition to the usual bedroom furnishings, an exer- cycle stands in one corner. Vicky comes into the room, goes to her dressing table, opens a bottom drawer and pushes things around until she finds a hidden candy bar. She starts to unwrap it, but the SOUND of the DOOR OPENING stops her. She drops the candy bar back into the drawer, and pushes it closed, as Jack comes in. He stands just inside the doorway, looking at her, and Vicky sees his reflection in the mirror. They're both uncomfortable, turn away. Then --

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: . I'm sorry...

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: So am I... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cc)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She holds up a thumb toward him -- a private symbol they have. Jack holds his up -- as if to press the thumbs together -- but they're still across the room from each other.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Friends? A beat... and they move toward each other... just close enough to press thumbs together.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Friends. But the aura of the quarrel is still there -- they drop their hands, and don't know what to do next. Jack looks over the sari... tries for a grin.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (continuing) You know... you do look pretty sexy in that thing. Vicky grins, then in a comical, but sexy way, she hands him an end of the sari, and they dance around each other as he unwraps it, while they hum some torchy song. Then they go into each other's arms. They kiss, begin to touch each other, run their hands over each other. Jack's hand reaches Vicky's buttocks. He squeezes.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (continuing; murmuring) There's the beautiful bun that split the pants. Vicky freezes, and then, furious, she pushes him away.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: You bought that pantsuit. I didn't.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You said you liked it.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: I would have liked it a size larger.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You were going to lose weight by the party. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: c) Cc) 8

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: I never said that. You said Thac.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You wanted that electronic calorie counter, and that exercycle thing. I got them for you.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: I didn't want them. You wanted them.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: What do you want? Ten cream puffs?

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: They're mostly air.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Vicky, it's not a joke. You're eating yourself right back to where you were when Danny was born. Why?

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: (comical question) I'm hungry?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (cynically paraphrasing) That's funny, you don't look hungry.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: That's not funny!

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: No, it's not, Vicky! And it gets less funny by the pound. Vicky glares at him, and suddenly grabs a blanket off the bed. Jack, knowing what's coming, has his hand up ready -- Vicky throws the blanket, and he catches it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack is asleep on the couch, his head completely covered by the blanket. LISA, 11, and DANNY, 9, in their pajamas, sneak up to the couch. Danny lifts the cover carefully, so they can see who it is. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (disappointed) It's Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: That'll be a nickel. As they go back to the bedrooms --

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Bet a dime the fight was about Mom eating too much. And they're gone. Jack wakes up, gets his bearings, realizing where he is and why. He gets up, stretches, and drops to the floor to do pushups.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicky wakes up, realizes she's alone in the bed -- remembers the fight, and pulls the covers up again. A beat, she throws off the covers, gets up, turns on the exercycle but doesn't get on it, and marches past it to the adjoining bathroom. We SEE her through the open door as she steps on the scale -- and groans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cake and cookies are in covered containers on the counters, sugared cereals are SEEN in open cupboards. The table is set for a fancy breakfast for four. Lisa puts the flower centerpiece in the middle, where three containers of syrup already stand along with jam and powdered sugar. Jack sets down a tray of hot pancakes. And Danny leads Vicky in. They're all dressed for the day, but Vicky is half asleep and in her robe.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (warily) Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: We made breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: I'm not hungry.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Aw, Mom... Daddy said we were all going to eat together. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Like we do every time you have a fight.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: ... I'll just have coffee. She sits down, and Jack pours coffee for her. She avoids Jack's eager look and sips at the coffee.

dialogues.speaker: A FEW MINUTES LATER 12
dialogues.text: Danny and Jack are just finishing their breakfast. Lisa is poking at hers, half of it is still on the plate. Should we go out and let you talk now, like after all the fights?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Yes. Danny and Lisa get up as ~-

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Are you driving, Daddy, like after all the --

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Lisa, knock it off. Lisa shrugs, and starts out after Danny.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: You didn't finish your breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: I'm not hungry. And she goes. Vicky and Jack are alone. She's staring into her coffee... Jack looking at her... then --

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Friends? He holds up his thumb... a beat... and Vicky presses hers against it.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Friends. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She pulls her hand away, uses both hands to hold the coffee cup, and looks away from him again.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: ... You want to meet me downtown and we'll go out to dinner?

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Why is the peace offering food? I thought you wanted me to diet.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Well... you won't let me buy you clothes... Flowers! I'll buy you flowers.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: I've got a garden full of flowers.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: To wake up tomorrow a size 9.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Then go to Dr. Haymer... He did it for you before.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Yeah, when I was a kid, and a teenager, and after each baby. He's a lousy doctor. The disease keeps coming back... worse every time.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (takes her hand) But in between, Vick, when you get thin... you were gorgeous when we got married. . (moves in closer) You can look like that again. He leans over to kiss her -- just as Lisa comes in.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: We're ready, Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Lisa, you've got lousy timing. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Sorry. And she goes. But she's broken the mood. Jack gets up.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Go to him, Vicky... You can be the sexiest, most beautiful woman in the world. _ He blows her a kiss, and goes. Vicky reaches up and grabs it, and mutters to herself.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Would it be okay if I was only the second most beautiful? She sits a moment, thinking. We HEAR the FRONT DOOR CLOSE. Without thinking, Vicky picks up the remaining cold pancake from Lisa's plate and begins to eat it.

dialogues.speaker: A MEDICAL POSTER 13
dialogues.text: of a normal heart and a heart covered with fat. STAY on that as:

dialogues.speaker: DR. HAYMER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: A candy bar is 250 calories, a piece of pie is 300, a serving of peanuts, 400. WIDEN THE SHOT TO INCLUDE Vicky in DR. HAYMER's office, sitting across the desk from the doctor, an old femily friend.

dialogues.speaker: DR. HAYMER
dialogues.text: (continuing) Calories are energy. If you don't use up the energy, it gtores itself in your body as at.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: And 3500 calories of stored fat is one pound of body weight. I know all that, Dr. Haymer.

dialogues.speaker: DR. HAYMER
dialogues.text: I know you know it. So why do you buy that stuff? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: ao

dialogues.text: I don't. I get it for the kids.

dialogues.speaker: DR. HAYMER
dialogues.text: Who eats their leftovers?

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: (a beat, grins) Oh... leftovers...

dialogues.speaker: DR. HAYMER
dialogues.text: (hands her a printed sheet) Vicky, go on a diet.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: (looks at the form and puts it down) I went on this diet.

dialogues.speaker: DR. HAYMER
dialogues.text: Went where? Off of it?

dialogues.speaker: INT, SUPERMARKET
dialogues.text: Busy -- women and men of all sizes, filling carts with food -- junk, health, lots of both. Above their heads, advertising banners offering a cornucopia of goodies -- desserts, starches, dietetic products, ete., etc. OVER all this:

dialogues.speaker: VICKY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Maybe it's my glands. We PUSH DOWN an aisle, diet foods on one side, gourmet bakery on the other, and FIND Vicky and Marge shopping. Vicky looks at the display of diet supplements with a before and after picture of a woman in profile, then joins Marge picking out baked goods as:

dialogues.speaker: DR. HAYMER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It's not glands. It's food. Too much food. The wrong kinds of food. Vicky, it's poison, it'll kill you.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: So let me go back on those appetite depresents -- those amphetamines. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DR. HAYMER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: No, you got crazy on amphetamines. Vicky and Marge are near a slim demonstrator, offering tidbits of a rich cake. They stop to taste as:

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: So I asked him if I should take some tests or see an endocrinologist or something.

dialogues.speaker: MARGE
dialogues.text: What'd he say? Marge takes two more samples, gives one to Vicky and they move on, past a huge man shoving cans of diet foods into his cart, as:

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: (imitating Haymer) If you want to spend your money, spend your money. But go on a diet. (looks at cake in her hand) I ean't start a diet in the middle of a day. : They round the corner to the candy aisle as:

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: (continuing) There ought to be a magic wand. A touch and the fat just melts off.

dialogues.speaker: . MARGE
dialogues.text: Or a touch and no one cares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicky and Marge roll their overfilled carts out of the store, past the drugstore where a window display ad- vertises diet pills, and to Vicky's station wagon as:

dialogues.speaker: MARGE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Did you know they used to sell capsules of worms that would eat your fat from inside? Yuch.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Marge, we have to do something about ourselves! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARGE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Why? What's wrong with us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a street of small stores, we briefly NOTICE a bill- board advertising ice cream -- a bikinied girl eating a cone... and then FOCUS ON Vicky's station wagon, loaded with groceries, and Marge as passenger.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Wouldn't you like to look like Patty?

dialogues.speaker: MARGE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Did -you ever see how Patty eats? The station wagon turns a corner and pulls up into the line of cars double-parked.in front of an elementary school. Mostly mothers, a few fathers, sit at their wheels waiting.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Yeah, She doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicky and Marge are sharing a bag of doughnuts as:

dialogues.speaker: MARGE
dialogues.text: What a lousy way to live.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Why? Patty's got it made... A great job, a macho live-in boyfriend, the same figure she had when she was eighteen. You know what I have? A 24 hour job -- being a maid to two kids, a house, and a husband who's looking for girls with figures like I had at eighteen.

dialogues.speaker: MARGE
dialogues.text: You know what I have? I like myself. Which is more than either of you have. school. Immediately, a CACAPHONY OF HORNS is HEARD -- -_ The school BELL RINGS and the children burst out of th ~ parents summoning their kids. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The kids look about, confused. Danny seeks out Vicky's car from the school door, then seeing it, makes a beeline for the car. He dives into the back seat and lies down. We're vaguely AWARE of another boy, his age, Jeff, watching.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Mind if we wait for Lisa and Peggy? Jeff saunters to the car, and Danny cringes away from him. Jeff grins at Danny, looks at Vicky, then back at Danny. He puffs his cheeks out, comically grotesque, and as Danny leans out the window, Jeff waddles away.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (calling after Jeff) Creep!

dialogues.speaker: MARGE
dialogues.text: What's all that about? Danny doesn't answer. Lisa and Marge's daughter, Peggy, appear at the school door, stop to talk to others. Danny leans over the front seat, and hits the HORN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're CLOSE ON the door on which is printed: DR. EUGENIA ROLLINS/ENDOCRINOLOGIST. An overweight man opens the door to go in, and we FOLLOW to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The walls display charts and medical textbook pictures of weight related subjects: body types, good and bad foods, slogans, etc. Men, women and children, most of them overweight, studiously avoid speaking to each other. Vicky is as quiet as the rest, flipping through a medical journal, but actually studying those around her. A NURSE opens the inside door.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Mrs. Matthews. And Vicky goes inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DR. ROLLINS is a small compact woman. She's business~- like, and yet gentle, as:

dialogues.speaker: DR. ROLLINS
dialogues.text: Over half the people in this country weigh more than they should. And they spend 10 billion dollars every year on fad diets, gadgets, pills, books, clinics. All they really need is to eat fewer calories.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: But, sometimes isn't it something the body is doing wrong?

dialogues.speaker: DR. ROLLINS
dialogues.text: Very, very few cases are due to body irregularity.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: But my tests... didn't they show anything?

dialogues.speaker: DR. ROLLINS
dialogues.text: Your blood pressure is 130 over 95, it could be lower, but it's normal, Your sugar level is 120. 100 is better, but it's normal. But if you gain more weight, those figures could change -- drastically.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: What about my glands?

dialogues.speaker: DR. ROLLINS
dialogues.text: Sorry. The only thing you can blame is your fatty cells.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: (a reprieve, she thinks) Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: DR. ROLLINS
dialogues.text: We're all born with a certain amount of fatty cells. There are two times in our lives when they multiply. If we're fat as toddlers, or in our late teens. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She shows

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: (sinks) Guilty.

dialogues.speaker: DR. ROLLINS
dialogues.text: Once they're there, they stay there. Vicky the chart -- two sketches of fatty cells -- the sketch of the empty cells is small, the one with the filled cells is large, but both contain the same number of cells. She shrugs

dialogues.speaker: DR. ROLLINS
dialogues.text: (continuing) You see, if you keep them empty, they stay small, and you stay slim. But if -you fill them up...

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: (really shaken now) What can I do?

dialogues.speaker: DR. ROLLINS
dialogues.text: Take care of yourself.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: I'm too busy taking care of everyone else.

dialogues.speaker: DR. ROLLINS
dialogues.text: {takes a diet sheet from drawer, the same one Dr. Haymer gave Vicky) You have time to go on a thousand calorie diet. And do aerobic exercises -- jog, swim, bike, jump rope. That will change your metabolism and burn the calories off faster... But most important, Vicky. Get at the source. Why?

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: (this is the nitty gritty, she's upset) I don't know why. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DR. ROLLINS
dialogues.text: Find out. I'm no psychologist, but I know people usually overeat for emotional reasons. Because they're unhappy, or to make up for something else they're lacking.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Or maybe it's just a vice, like drinking or drugs... only it shows more.

dialogues.speaker: DR. ROLLINS
dialogues.text: Then get rid of it. Try a group . Weight Watchers or Overeaters Anonymous or Calorie Counters. Vicky looks more and more overwhelmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's early evening. Jack and Lisa are working on the dining room table. Lisa, on homework; Jack, pay- ing bills. The room is adjacent to the kitchen, so that at some ANGLES we can SEE Vicky in there, making dinner. The counter is filled with riches for tonight -- mashed potatoes, sauces, a cake. Vicky is prepar- ing garlic toast, wets a finger to pick up 4 erumb, and eats it as:

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: So join one of them.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: You know what they cost?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Whatever. I'11 pay.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: You're still grumbling about paying for the gym.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: $300 a year for four years! And you never use it!

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: (comes to the door) I never wanted it! (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VICKY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It was one of your. 'helpful' hints! Like that damned exercycle in the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: And you never use that either!

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: . Are you going to fight? Lisa -- TACK

dialogues.speaker: ISA
dialogues.text: Bye... LIS She gathers her books quickly and goes, as --

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: I don't want to fight with you, Jack,

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I know. You want a magic wand.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: (trying to be funny) You think if they could go to the moon --

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Vicky. Go to a diet club. A beat, Vicky shrugs and goes back into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: I'm not a joiner. Jack follows her, and we FOLLOW.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: (continuing) You want roquefort on the salad?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Vicky, go somewhere... before you turn into a Mack truck! Vicky freezes. And Jack could bite his tongue --

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (continuing) I'm sorry. But Vicky is taking off her apron. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (continuing) Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Somewhere! As ordered! She throws the apron at him and marches into the din- ing room. Jack follows, and we FOLLOW.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: What about dinner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Lisa appears, playing the "sweet child."

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: I'll make it, Daddy. Vicky hears that, grows even more angry, as she marches into her bedroom and slams the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gym is filled with men and women in sweatsuits, a few with weight belts, some of the really svelte women are in leotards, and all the heavy people are sweating profusely. They follow the male instructor through a rigorous exercise, bouncing in place in a jogging-like movement, to recorded MUSIC, and keeping up with vary- ing degrees of success, as we PAN:

dialogues.speaker: VICKY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (imitating Lisa) I'll make it, Daddy... the fink.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Let her. Let them all take turns cooking, and let Jack do the chauffeuring, baby sit a couple of nights so you can get out. And now we're on Vicky and Patty, next to each other. Patty is gorgeous in her leotard, and doing her exer- cise with ease. Vicky, in a sweatsuit, is barely mov- ing through it, breathing heavily. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: (continuing; cynically) You don't have to be the sweet, self-sacrificing housewife every minute of the day.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Yes, I do... Jack's entitled to a good housewife or a good-looking . wife. TI have to be at least one of then. She stops for a breath, as the rest of the class keeps going.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: What about what you're entitled to?

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: (trying the exercise again) I've got it.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Kids, husband, home... ‘PATTY Is it what you want? New exercise -- harder -- sit-ups -- and Vicky can only get her head and shoulders off the floor. She hesi- tates, then nods, yes.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: (continuing) Are you ever going back to work? You were a damned good advertising artist.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: That was 12 years ago. The thought depresses her. The class is getting into shoulder stands for bicycling. Patty gets into it easily. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: You going to just sit there? Vicky tries it -- once, twice... a third time. She rolls over, too far, and does a clumsy backward somer- sault. And then lies there, defeated.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Oh, the hell with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SOUND of EXERCISE MUSIC is still HEARD, as Vicky, worn out, almost limps out of the gym. As she turns toward the parking lot to one side, we WIDEN THE SHOT TO INCLUDE the store between the gym and the parking lot -- an ice cream shop. Vicky gets just past it, hesitates, looks at the store, hungrily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pictures of luscious ice cream combinations line the walls. Vicky, wedged into a half-armed student chair, about to attack a large sundae complete with trimmings, scoops up the cherry, and when it's halfway to her mouth --

dialogues.speaker: INCLUDING JOYCE 26
dialogues.text: a jolly, very overweight women in her mid-30's, sits at right angles to Vicky. Vicky sees her when she lifts her head to eat the cherry. Vicky hesitates -- it's as if she's seen a mirror image of herself -- and she doesn't like it. Joyce looks up -- their eyes catch, and they're embarrassed. They've been caught in the act. Finally --

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Don’t eat the cherry. Red dye number two, It's bad for you. A beat -- and they both laugh. Vicky shrugs a "what the hell" and digs in. They go on eating as:

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: You live around here?

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Of course not. I wouldn't eat ice cream where people know me. They might think I'm fat. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They go on eating. Joyce finishes, struggles to get out of the chair, starts to leave, then stops for:

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: (continuing) My name is Joyce and I'm a compulsive overeater. That's how we say it at 0.A.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: You belong to Overeaters Anonymous?

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Did, Also Weight Watchers, Calorie Counters and TOPS. And as you can see, I gained a great deal from all of them. Vicky grins, laughs, and in a moment, they're both giggling uncontrollably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicky and Joyce leave the store together, as if they're great, old friends, and walk toward the parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Then there were only three left, and I couldn't serve that to six women, sO --

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: You polished them off, and went to the store for more.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Yeah. I was so sick the next day --

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Did it stop you from eating? Vicky doesn't need to answer... they walk a minute, then --

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: The doctor said I should figure out why... and I thought of a million reasons... all phony. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: oD)

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: I know why I eat... it's the only pleasure I have. They've reached Joyce's car.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Well... bon appetit. She starts getting into the car, and Vicky reaches out impulsively to stop her.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Joyce, can I call you?

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: For the next ice cream sundae?

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Or the next confessional, which ever comes first. Joyce digs into her purse for pencil or paper, as --

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: You'll never use this.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Probably not. She takes the slip of paper with Joyce's phone number on it, and Joyce gets into the car. Vicky watches as she drives off, then looks at the phone number, puts it into her purse, and starts toward her own car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa sits in front of the TV eating popcorn, and watching an old "Lucy" or ? rerun -- a funny dinner scene. But she's turned to what Jack and Vicky are saying. Vicky has just come in, and Jack is leading her toward Danny's room, as --

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: He wouldn't tell me. He just ran into his room and slammed the door. But you should have seen him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: He looks terrible.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Of all the nights for you not to be here. Vicky goes to Danny's door and knocks.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Danny?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Go away!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny is in his pajamas, and huddled into the bed, with his back to Vicky. She picks up his shirt from the floor, notices the rips, dirt and blood on it, and goes with it to the bed. She sits down and turns him toward her. Danny has made a childish, unsuccess~ ful attempt to clean his face, but the dirt, and remnants of a bloody nose are still SEEN.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: ... How's the other guy?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I barely touched him... He's got the longest arms!

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff Hauser! He didn't mean to tell her. He turns away, and pushes down into the covers.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: The creep?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I'll get him back...

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: For what? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: For... for giving me a bloody nose, and tearing my shirt and --

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: For what, Danny? A beat... and Danny has to let it out -- on a sob.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: He said you had to go through doors sideways... he said... boy was I lucky, I didn't have a mother, I had an elephant... he said... And he can't talk any more, he's sobbing too hard. Vicky holds back her own tears... but the pain is obvious. Vicky holds her arms out to him, and Danny goes into them. She holds him, rocking him... as he sobs and she bites at her lips. FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A busy place; waiters carry trays heaped with rich food, pastry carts stand waiting, menus are huge. Baskets piled high with homemade rolls are on every table. A fashion MODEL in a flowing, long gown poses for the women at one table, and a slender luncher, watching, rejects a basket of hot biscuits/rolls offered by a waiter. We FOLLOW the Model toward another table, where someone lathers a roll with butter... and then MOVE PAST that toward another table where Vicky and Marge are finishing their lunches. Vicky's eating a tuna salad, and Marge, a club sandwich with French fries. A WAITRESS refills their coffee cups.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Oh, didn't you get rolls?

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Yes, but I didn't want -- But the Waitress is gone. Marge starts to ladle sugar into her coffee, as Vicky squeezes some lemon onto her salad and picks up what she's been saying:

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: (continuing) I didn’t know what to say to Danny. ‘I'm not fat?' ‘It's okay that I'm fat?' ‘Jeff's a stinking brat and you should beat him up'?... which is what T wanted to say. Marge, why don't you use artificial sweetener in your coffee?

dialogues.speaker: MARGE
dialogues.text: That stuff kills rats. Two men take the table behind Vicky; the one back to back with her, pushing his chair quite close in order to sit down. The Waitress appears with two baskets of rolls, putting one on the men's table, and one on icky's.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: There you are. She leaves. Vicky puts the basket on an adjacent, empty table -- where the first basket of umeaten rolls sits, as Marge grabs one. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARGE
dialogues.text: What you should have said is, "Poor Jeff, he tries to cuddle with his mother and he hits rib bones. You've got it made, kid.' The Model approaches their table, opening her gown to reveal a matching bikini.

dialogues.speaker: MODEL
dialogues.text: (reciting) Going from beach to beach party and made out of imported silk, the ensemble comes in blue, gold and green, sizes six to twelve, and sells for $57.95.

dialogues.speaker: MARGE
dialogues.text: What do you have in a size 20?

dialogues.speaker: MODEL
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. Both shrug. The Model leaves and Marge reaches for another roll. As she butters it:

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: That's 120 calories each and you're on your third.

dialogues.speaker: MARGE
dialogues.text: Vicky, I didn't go on pills with you, and I didn't go on shots with you, and I'm not going on 1000 calories with you either. So, let me enjoy this. They eat silently, then:

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Do you know what I weigh?

dialogues.speaker: MARGE
dialogues.text: No, and I don't want to.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Don't worry, I wouldn't tell you. The Waitress returns and picks up their plates.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: There's dessert with the salad. Peach cobbler. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: ~ Do you have any fresh fruit?

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Sorry, no substitutions.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: I'll skip it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'll take it and I'll have one, too -- with chocolate ice cream.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: I don't want... But the Waitress has gone.

dialogues.speaker: MARGE
dialogues.text: You can start your diet tomorrow. The cobbler here is really great.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: I've already started and I'm not o~ going to let you ruin it for me. ww / MARGE Then I'll eat both cobblers. They're pretty small anyway.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: No! No, I'll eat it, I know I will. Vicky gets up.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: (continuing) If I'm here when the cobbler arrives, I'll eat it.

dialogues.speaker: MARGE
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: To make a phone call. I'll meet you up front. Vicky tries to move from the table but is stuck because the man behind her is so close. He's involved in con- oo versation and is oblivious to her struggle until:

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: ~ (continuing) Could you move... just an inch? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The man shifts his chair closer to his table, while giving Vicky an amused once-over. Vicky catches it, is embarrassed, and covers with:

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: (continuing; to the man) Better not eat the rolls. You're getting paunchy. And she goes, hearing the men LAUGH behind her. We TRACK Vicky through the restaurant... and the eating, and the piles of food, and the waiters serving -- and Vicky trying not to look at passing goodies. She goes to the coin telephone on the wall near the cashier. She gets Joyce's number from her purse, dials, and gets a busy signal. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cc)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She hangs up, turns to watch Marge, now eating the cobbler a la mode, turns away; notices after-dinner mints on the cashier's counter, takes one, almost eats it, puts it back, and dials again. Busy. And she's getting very upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an office, with a large desk, covered with papers -- notes, invoices, mail, etc. Joyce {wear- ing a ratty old muu-muu) leans back in the tilting swivel chair, in a sexy, come-on way, as she talks into the phone... and nibbles on nuts from a bowl on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Well, I'm wearing a sheer black negligee... Because I knew I was calling you... Now?... In the middie of the day?... No, come on, Max, don't be silly... I didn't call you for that, I called you to tell you that we're having a special on number 20 bonded paper... Just for you, $3.95 a ream... Well, why don't you place your order, and I'll ask my boss if I can make the delivery in person. She begins to write the order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She dials again, this time the phone is free. A waiter carries two huge banana splits past her, and she watches, as:

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: (into the phone) Hello, is this Joyce?... From the ice cream store, and no maraschino cherries?... Yeah, Vicky... Oh, I'm fine -- no, I'm not... I just had lunch -- (shrugs) No, I didn't have dessert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like a page out of House Beautiful. Everything Joyce can't put on her body, she puts into her home. She sets out dishes of ice cream for herself and Vicky, who looks at it, worriedly.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: It's dietetic. No sugar, no salt, and they don't say how many calories. As they eat:

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Marge says she's the only one who's really happy, because she accepts who she is, and enjoys it, And she's right. Patty's got it all, but she isn't enjoying it.. I've got everything Patty doesn't have . and I'm miserable.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: I have nothing. No husband, no kids, and a lousy job. And I'm fatter than all of you.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: What do you'want, Joyce?

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Husband, kids, and no job. What about you?

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: I don't know... I used to do advertising art. Patty says I should go back to it.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Is that what you want?

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: - I'd have to take some classes first.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: So take some classes.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: I'd have to lose weight first.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: (understanding) Big lady wrapped around a little paint brush? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: I'd look ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: So go to Jack La Lanne.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: I was thinking... Calorie Counters? Will you go with me? They both think about it, as they scrape all the ice eream off their plates and eat it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicky has on a bulky dress and some junk jewelry -- necklace and bracelets. She is edgy as she checks herself in the mirror and doesn't realize Jack is taking a picture until the flash of his Polaroid goes off,

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: What're you doing?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: That's the 'before' picture. When you get down, I'll take the ‘after.' And Vicky is more edgy.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Did I tell you it's $10 for the first time for registration? After that, $5 a week?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You told me, and I'll pay it. Vicky goes into the bathroom. We SEE her through the open doorway. She gets on the scale and takes off the jewelry, as:

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: You have to pay the $5 even the weeks I don't go.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You already planning which weeks you won't go? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: I'm trying to be realistic. The dress feels too heavy, she takes it off, and steps on the scale again -- then in her slip, she comes back into the bedroom to test the weight of other dresses in the closet, as:

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Forget realistic. Lose weight. A beat. Vicky looks at herself in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Jack... what do you see when you look at me?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You trying to get out of going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not asking you to go to bed with me... I want to know how you feel about me.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I feel... Honest?

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Honest.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I feel... betrayed... A beat. He walks out, and Vicky looks at herself, wondering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under a beautifully-lettered slogan, "God will pro- vide is a crudely homemade one on paper, “But not too well, please!" And under that ‘Calorie Counters." The room is filled with people -- coming in, chatting, standing in line to check in, and in another line to get weighed. Joyce and Vicky, wearing a lightweight sleeveless dress, reach the front of the check-in line, and are greeted by SANDRA, tightly girdled into a fairly nice figure. The check-in counter top is covered with pamphlets and diet recipes. (CONTINUED)
o~ w 36 on

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: (effusively) Oh, Joyce, I'm so glad you came back!

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: I didn't come back. I was dragged back. This is my friend, Vicky, she wants to join.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: (same tone as before) Oh, Vicky, I'm so glad you want to join! BEN approaches. He's 40ish, 25 pounds overweight, a smiling, likeable man.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: (to Joyce) Couldn't stay away from me, could you?

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Ben! I thought you'd be skinny by now.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: I was... for about ten minutes.

dialogues.speaker: THE WEIGH-IN LINE 36
dialogues.text: Joyce, Vicky and Ben are now together in line, in that order. A woman, BETTY, 60 pounds overweight, is in front of Joyce. They move up slowly as:

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: I'm giving it one more chance. After that, I'll start saving up for a by-pass.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: (to Vicky) Ben's doctor thinks the weight caused his heart attack. Vicky looks at him, shocked.

dialogues.speaker: , BEN
dialogues.text: Actually, I'm not overweight. My chest just slipped a little. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: It's Joyce's turn. She steps around the free-stand- ing blackboard used as a divider, and gets onto the scale, which is hidden from those in line -- but not from us. As she hands her card to the clerk:

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Close your eyes, this is supposed to be private.

dialogues.speaker: THE GROUP 37
dialogues.text: is now almost seated. As the last people take seats, the lecturer, BRAD, 30ish, very slender, and dressed ultra-mod (with shirt open to the belt line, chains around his neck, etc.), leads the group, singing, as we PICK OUT Vicky, Joyce and Ben sitting toward the back. Vicky is reading the song off a leaflet, but Ben and Joyce know it, and sing along with less gusto than most around them. Several people wear half-masks of pigs' faces. Joyce and Ben hold their masks on their laps.

dialogues.speaker: ALL
dialogues.text: (to the tune of “Home on the Range") Oh, give us a shape, And don't let us escape To the land where the fat used to be. Oh, let us get thin Because thin's always in. And to happiness it is the key. Everyone applauds, then:

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Good evening. I'm Brad.

dialogues.speaker: ALL
dialogues.text: (in chorus) Good evening, Brad.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: My name used to be Irving. When I weighed 235 pounds. But I look more like a Brad now, wouldn't you say? The audience APPLAUDS and AD-LIBS approval.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: (continuing) Let's see how we did this week. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: c )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: AD-LIBBED mixture of GROANS and HURRAHS, as Brad picks up a pile of cards.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: (continuing) Betty? Betty stands at her seat for:

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Four and a quarter pounds! APPLAUSE. She sits down.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Betty's lost 14 pounds in all. It won't be long now! AD-LIBBED approval, Brad looks at the next card.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: (continuing) Oh-oh. AD-LIBBED GROANS of compassion.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: (continuing) Now, you know we don't announce the amount of gain, but we do want to help... Joyce, what happened, darling?

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: (doesn't stand, comically) I don't know, I ate like a bird.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: A vulture? Everyone laughs, including Joyce... but we CATCH Vicky's face... she's mortified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The participants are now in casual resort wear, learn- ing disco dancing from the DISCO INSTRUCTOR, a very slender chorus boy type. Vicky is keeping up better than most -- and Gary is right beside her.

dialogues.speaker: DISCO INSTRUCTOR
dialogues.text: And dip... and again... and start over -- front left, right, left, kick and turn and -- the same -- And they go on, Vicky getting more sure of herself and adding a frill or two of her own. Gary turns to her, and they become a twosome as the others continue in the straight lines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The floor and walls are covered with machines to pull and tighten every muscle in the body. Three walls are mirrored. The fourth leads to the jacuzzi, which is an ell off the gym, and the sauna and steam room, visible through steamy glass doors. Most of the machines are in use -- a heavy woman is giggling as the vibrating machine jiggles her bottom, a man struggles unsuccessfully with a pulley, people on slant boards do a variety of things with their arms and legs. A man comes from the sauna, wrapped in a towel, and nearly fainting -- a woman comes from the steam room, also wrapped in towels and nearly faint- ing -- they stumble past each other; he goes to the steam room, she into the sauna. We MOVE IN CLOSER to the jacuzzi. In the bubbling water, people relax against the water jets, or swim lazily about. We PICK OUT Vicky, sitting beside her jogging partner, Gary.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Staying long?

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: A week.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Two weeks. I'm Gary Radford. Chicago. Single. I'm in electronics.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Vicky Matthews. Los Angeles. Separated. I'm... an artist... when I find a job.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: (moving closer) Oh, an artist. How interesting. It's a come~on, Vicky knows it, and isn't sure how to react... but she's enjoying it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PARTICIPANTS wear bulky robes or glamorous leisure outfits. They sit about tables for four, finishing tiny portions of very dietetic looking food. As we SLOWLY PAN the room, we pick up bits of conversation. First table: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: The saddest moment of the day is when I look down at my plate and there's nothing left. Second table:

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: I'd eat until I was sick -- and then take a triple dose of a good, strong laxative. Third table:

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: I've lost 755 pounds... in between gaining 874 pounds. Fourth table:

dialogues.speaker: . MAN
dialogues.text: That wasn't a forward pass, it was a forward fumble!

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: They call themselves a football team! Fifth table: Vicky sits with Gary; MARV, a paunchy older man; and SYLVIA, a well-preserved older woman.

dialogues.speaker: MARV
dialogues.text: You can't get jobs, you can't get insurance...

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: You can't find a decent dress. Half the people in the country are overweight, and all the stores carry junior miss. We PUSH IN CLOSE to Gary and Vicky, who are involved in their own conversation.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: After you start work, I'll come over and take you away from your drawing board. I get out here a couple times a year. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: oo VICKY (pleased with ~ herself) Okay... a couple of times a year you can take me away from my drawing board.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: How about tonight?

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: I don't have a drawing board here.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: I have a room.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: So do I. A single... But thanks for asking. . And they grin at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicky, in the robe she wore at dinner, is sprawled, exhausted, across the bed... and talking on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: ... L sound tired, because I am tired. But I'm feeling great... Joyce is picking me up... Mom ... Mom, let me talk to the kids ... Hi, Lisa, how are you?... That's nice... I never said he was a bad father. I said... Oh, hi, Danny, how are you?... Yeah, Lisa just told me... No, tell him I don't want to talk... (cooler) Hello, Jack... How's it going? : (growing angry) You can go skiing next week. The mountain will still be there . Jack, I'm going to hang up now... We can talk about it when I get back... I'm going to hang up now... Jack, I'm going to ~- And she pulls the phone from her ear, as Jack SLAMS oo , the PHONE DOWN. Vicky looks at the dead phone, and hangs it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's almost the end of a gym class. The class is on the floor doing sit ups -- with varying degrees of difficulty. Most are exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: . GYM INSTRUCTOR
dialogues.text: And one more time... all the way to your toes... and back... slowly . one vertebrae at a time. And they finish.

dialogues.speaker: GYM INSTRUCTOR
dialogues.text: (continuing) Not too shabby. Pool exercise in ten minutes. Let's go. - She bounces up, and goes out. Several people get up, more slowly, and go after her. A WOMAN heads for the scale in one corner. Another WOMAN watches.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN ON SCALE
dialogues.text: One quarter of a pound.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN WATCHING
dialogues.text: Don't drink water -- you'll gain it all back. They go out. Then only four people are left including Vicky, Gary, Marv and Sylvia, all lying on the floor, wiped out. They don't move for a moment. Then, still lying prone on the floor:

dialogues.speaker: MARV
dialogues.text: You know what we are? We're a bunch of masochists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not me. I'm a young woman wrapped in an old package... I'm trying to doll up the package.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm drying out. The others look at him, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: (continuing) And losing weight. Did you know a screwdriver has more calories than a chocolate doughnut? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: MARV
dialogues.text: So, who needs enemies, we've got ourselves. A beat, Vicky is really thinking now, really trying to figure it out.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Not me. I'm good to myself. Too good. That's why I have to come here every six months.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: That's not being good to yourself, going up and down like a yoyo.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Well, I like to eat.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: ... I'm not sure I do... Half the time I don't even know what I'm putting into my mouth.

dialogues.speaker: MARV
dialogues.text: Or how much.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: I don't think I eat because I'm hungry either... I don't let myself get hungry.

dialogues.speaker: MARV
dialogues.text: Yeah, my mouth's going all day, when does my stomach have time to get hungry?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: (to Vicky) “So why do you eat?

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: I don't know... It's... something . it gives me something.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: But that's not what you really want. (CONTINUED)
c)

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: No... what I really want is...

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: A job?

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: I want... to like myself.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: What's not to Like?

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Well, I'm... (looks in mirror) What's not to like? (to others) I'm not some kind of... rotten person, am 1? The others shake their heads in unison, no.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: (continuing) There is something to like. I'm a... a good daughter, and a good mother... (shrugs) . I wasn't a bad wife... (intently) I'm a pretty talented artist... (looks in mirror) . And I'm not that bad looking. Gary wolf whistles.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: (continuing) So... I don't have to eat. Looks in mirror, straightens up, does a bit of a model's stance, likes it, looks back at them, smiling broadly.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: (continuing) I_ don't have to eat! HOLD on Vicky.  c ) c )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gary, Sylvia and Marv wave goodbye as Vicky, in a fitted jump suit, throws her pag into the back seat of Joyce's car and gets in. Vicky is looking slimmer and terrific; Joyce is also slimmer, but very pale and wan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as they greet each other with a hug. Vicky studies Joyce worriedly.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: How are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: (as she pulls away) Great. Lost six pounds this week. How about you? .

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Seven.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Ah, ‘but I didn't have to move a muscle.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Ah, but moving muscles was so much fun!

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Oh?.... Tell me about him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce's car rounds a corner, and pulls to the curb as:

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: We've set the wedding date. October sixth. You're matron of honor.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I'd be honored. The car pulls up to Vicky's house. Helen's Ford really blocks both sides of the driveway. Jack's Mercedes is at the curb in front. Joyce pulls her car up be- ind it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: — VICKY You really going to stay on the protein until then?

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Until I get into that gown.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Are you all right, Joyce?

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: I feel fantastic. And you look fantastic. Go in there and show them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicky gets her bag out of Joyce's car, waves as Joyce pulls away, and then turns and faces the house. She pulls her stomach in, stands straighter and starts up the walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicky stands in the middle of the room and turns, like a model, as Helen, Jack, Lisa and Danny examine her. Danny is awed, Lisa unsure, Jack getting turned on and Helen unimpressed.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: How long will it last?

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mother, for the vote of confidence.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: You're beautiful, Mommy.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: (kissing him) Thank you, handsome. What do you think, Lisa?

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: You're so... different! And she runs to her own room.  q 88 89 87.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is combination frilly girl, and leftover child. Lisa is lying face down on the bed, and Vicky goes to her.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Hey... Lisa... I'm still me...

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: No, you're not. You're different.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Look at me. She picks Lisa up, and turns her so that they're face to face.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: (continuing) See? Same face. Same eyes, game nose, same mouth --

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Different chin.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: I should hope so... Lisa, I feel great about myself. Be happy for me! A beat.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Oh, Mommy... don't go away and leave me like Daddy did. A beat, and Vicky gathers Lisa into her arms and holds her tightly. HOLD on them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicky, drained from her session with Lisa, doesn't see Jack lying on the bed, trying to look sexy, as she comes in and unzips her jumpsuit.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You look fantastic. Vicky jumps, sees him, and tries to zip the suit back up, but she's nervous and the zipper sticks. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: I thought you'd left.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: No... I'm still here... Vicky can't budge the zipper, she holds the jumpsuit closed and sidles toward the closet.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: I thought... you'd be happy to get out of here... by now.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I thought so, too... Vicky hurriedly gets out of the jumpsuit and grabs something from the closet to put on, 4 filmy negligee. JACK. (continuing) Until I saw you. Vicky realizes what she's doing, throws the negligee into the closet and grabs a shapeless old chenille robe.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: So... did you have any problems?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Yes... I missed you. She turns away from him, getting the robe on, and Jack hurries over from the bed. When she turns back, he's face to face with her.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Oh...! She moves away from him, and he follows as: JACK . It's been a long time, Vicky.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Not so long... actually... He grabs at her, and pulls her to him,

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I want you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VICKY ,
dialogues.text: So how come you walked out on me?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Well, you know what you were like before. Vicky stops struggling, looks at him, and shoves him away.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Well, this is after. Get out of my bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (getting angry) Surel... I pay for that fat farm, and that... that hippy gets the benefits, is that it? Vicky throws a pillow at him.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Out!

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You wouldn't take the weight off for me! Why'd you do it for him? Vicky throws another pillow.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: I did it for me! Can't you understand that? I did it for me. For mel FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike is painting at an easel and looks up to see Vicky, very angry, at his open door. He looks at her questioningly, and she slams the door hard. The bed comes down.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: (looking her over) Hey, you look fantastic!

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Do you know what Jack said?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: No. And I don't want to.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: (a beat) Neither do I. And she starts for the bed, taking off her jacket at the same time.

dialogues.speaker: TIME LAPSE 91
dialogues.text: Vicky and Mike are in bed, they've made love and are now nestled in each other's arms.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: So what did Jack say?

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: He said that I changed, that I'm a different person.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: “You are.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: You're sure of yourself, you know what you want.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: . I want a job.  91.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric is showing samples of Vicky's work to FRANK LESSER, a handsome, 40ish businessman... as Vicky watches nervously, and Mike protectively. Frank is interested in the work... but is more interested in Vicky.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (to Vicky) You'd have to start as an apprentice.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: No, I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: (taking Mike aside Just to start. He's giving her a job.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: He's giving her the business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: with Mike and Eric still arguing MOS in b.g.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: There'll be an opening in a week or two. I'll call you.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Great.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Maybe we can have lunch... or dinner? He takes her hand. Mike sees, starts toward them, and Eric holds him back. Eric. goes to show Frank out, leaving Mike and Vicky alone in the room.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: What was all that about... (caricaturing Frank) Lunch... ox dinner? (CONT INUED)

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: You almost blew it for me!

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: There's mothing to blow. He didn't offer you a job. He offered you... (caricaturing) Lunch... or dinner... and after that, who knows?

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Mike, he liked my work!

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: He barely looked at your work! The only thing he's interested in is you... as a... a sex object. Vicky reacts -- her, a sex object?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We HEAR the last strains of "THE WEDDING MARCH," as it ends.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It should only happen to you.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: fully decorated for a wedding. Joyce and Ben stand before the minister -- Joyce wearing her mother's wedding dress. It's tight, but it fits, She's really baggy-eyed and very sick looking, but also very happy. As is Ben, also slimmer. Among the guests are Vicky as matron of honor, standing close to the couple, Helen next to her, and elsewhere -- Mike with Lisa and Danny and Patty and Marge. A table laden with rich food and liquor is at the back of the room, wait- ing. Danny sneaks over for a taste as the ceremony goes on MOS as:

dialogues.speaker: HELEN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It could happen again... you could give up the hippy and find yourself a man. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VICKY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Shh, I'm listening to the ceremony. We HEAR the ceremony as an unintelligible MURMUR for a beat, as we MOVE IN CLOSE to Vicky and Helen, then it's MOS again, as:

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Or, if you came to your senses, you could get Jack back.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: I don't want Jack back.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: You can't support yourself.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Mom, please --

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: As bad as it was with your father, at least I had someone to take care of me. Vicky looks at her sharply -- opens her mouth for a sharp rebuttal -- and at that moment the ceremony is over. Vicky and Helen are caught in the mob of people going to congratulate the newlyweds, and others head- ing for the food; they try to hear each other over that.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: What was so bad about my father?

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: (louder) Why are you always picking on my father? A couple of people look their way, and Vicky, embar- rassed, takes Helen's arm and steers her away from the mob. As they pass Mike on his way to the newly- weds:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Tell Joyce and Ben congratulations and I'll be right back. Helen shrugs an 'y.don't-know-what 's-going-on" to Mike, as Vicky pushes her toward the back of the room.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE THE RESTROOMS IN THE CHAPEL 96
dialogues.text: Vicky steers Helen toward the women's restroom.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: What are you doing? Vicky opens the restroom door, but the room is packed with women waiting their turn. She eloses the door on them, and pushes Helen toward the men's restroom near- by.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: (continuing) I knew it, she's going crazy. Just as they start to open the men's room door, a MAN comes out, checking his fly.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: What?... As Vicky shoves Helen inside.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: We can't go in there!

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: You can't go in therel And the door closes. We can HEAR the lock turn.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: If you have something to do in here, do it, and let's go back to the wedding.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: After we get something settled.  98 99 100 101 95.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO THE CHAPEL 98
dialogues.text: People are milling around now, the children chasing each other. Joyce looks about, sees Mike, who's looking off toward the restrooms. She works her way through the crowd, accepting congratulations, and gets to Mike.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Where's Vicky?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: In the men's room. Joyce and Patty, near her, do takes, and Mike shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: You're always picking on me, and you're always picking on Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: What did I say? I said he supported me.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: No, what you said is, I can't support myself. And T can!

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO THE CHAPEL
dialogues.text: Joyce, Patty and Mike approach the door, and Marge is pushing through people to get to them. Joyce knocks .as Lisa and Danny join them.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Is Mom in there?

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Look what you're doing to your life!

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: All right, look what I'm doing! I have a job -- almost. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: There's a Vicky and 96. 101

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Apprentice. Thirty-four years old, and she's going to be an apprentice.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Thirty-two! KNOCK.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE 0.8.
dialogues.text: Vicky, is anything wrong?

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: You had a husband, and a home, and a decent life --

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: It wasn't enough!

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Oh, you're so independent!

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Yes, I aml Finally, I am!

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Vicky, come on out.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: How about your children?

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: I'll support them.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: A child needs a father!

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: A child needs a mother, too! Helen glare at each other, as:

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What's the matter? Is it out of order? :

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: I was a good mother... I gave you everything you needed.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Food! You gave me food! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: What should I have done? Starved you?

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: I needed more than that. I needed you to... to tell me that I was... pretty... and smart... and talented...

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Like your father did. He gave you a big head, your father,

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: He made me feel... like I was somebody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: LISA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mom and Grandma are fighting!

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (excited) Wow, are they ever!

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: I don't understand that you're talking about.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Mom, I needed you to believe in me +» $0 I could believe in myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vicky, are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: -.. Is that why you were so... so tight with him?... Your father?...

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: He believed in me.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: (wistfully) You were so close, the two of you.

dialogues.speaker: MARGE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Vicky, please, come out. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: (realizing) Mom...? Were you jealous?... Of me? Helen's look is the answer -- yes.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Vicky, I'm coming in there!

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: It was always the two of you... together...

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: He loved you so much...

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: He was so proud of you.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: (on an incredulous giggle) I think we were rivals.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: ... That's ridiculous... She starts to giggle.

dialogues.speaker: VICKY
dialogues.text: Ridiculous... The giggling grows into a relieved guffaw. Vicky puts her arms out, and Helen, like a little girl, goes into them. They've reversed roles. Vicky rocks her gently, as the laughter subsides.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO THE CHAPEL
dialogues.text: There's a mob in front of the door now -- all staring as Vicky and Helen, their arms about each other, come out. Over that a high-pitched TV ANNOUNCER'S VOICE:

dialogues.speaker: TV ANNOUNCER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: All your troubles are over -- or will be --

dialogues.text: A split-screen picture of a woman -- before and after. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: The before grotesque and frowning; the after, pencil thin -- and smiling sexily.
